# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Center

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority made significant progress in 2024 in strengthening Hong Kong’s position as a globally competitive international financial centre.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), in collaboration with relevant mainland and Hong Kong authorities, has introduced a series of measures to jointly deepen and expand the connectivity between Hong Kong and mainland financial markets. These include optimizing the "Cross-boundary Wealth Management Connect Scheme," expanding the eligible collateral scope for the HKMA's RMB liquidity arrangements and the "Northbound Swap Connect," optimizing the "Northbound Swap Connect," and improving the primary liquidity provider arrangements. These initiatives will help strengthen Hong Kong's role as a gateway and consolidate its position as the global offshore RMB business hub.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has also made solid progress in consolidating the competitiveness of Hong Kong's financial platform, covering areas such as bond issuance, asset and wealth management, green and sustainable finance, and corporate treasury centers. To promote Hong Kong's financial services, the HKMA has enhanced market promotion efforts targeting overseas and mainland stakeholders, enabling them to fully understand the soundness of Hong Kong's financial system and the opportunities it brings. The third "Global Financial Leaders’ Investment Summit" and several other major events were successfully held, not only enhancing Hong Kong's image as a leading international financial center but also generating positive ripple effects. The HKMA actively participates in various international and regional central banks and regulatory organizations, continuing to contribute to global efforts in maintaining financial stability and promoting the development of financial markets.

The Financial Supervisory Commission has made significant progress in all areas of the "Fintech 2025" strategy, including central bank digital currency and data infrastructure.

The registration numbers and transaction volume of the Faster Payment System FPS continue to grow steadily, reaching 15.8 million registrations by the end of 2024. The average daily processing of Hong Kong dollar real-time transactions increased to 1.65 million. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is working closely with the People’s Bank of China to implement interconnection between FPS and the mainland’s online payment interbank clearing system, facilitating cross-border payments.

# Overview

In 2024, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority continued to be committed to enhancing Hong Kong's competitiveness as an international financial center.

The HKMA has expanded and optimized the mutual connectivity mechanisms between Hong Kong and the Mainland, which helps consolidate Hong Kong’s role as a bridge between the Mainland and international financial markets. Several optimization measures related to the “Cross-boundary Wealth Management Connect Scheme” (WMC) were introduced this year, facilitating cross-border investment by individual investors in the Greater Bay Area (GBA). In February, the HKMA added the onshore government bonds issued by the Ministry of Finance and the policy financial bonds issued by Mainland policy banks to the list of eligible collateral under the RMB liquidity injection arrangement. In July, relevant departments in both jurisdictions announced further support for overseas investors to use onshore bonds held through Bond Connect as collateral for Northbound Swap Connect transactions, to be implemented in January 2025. In addition, Northbound Swap Connect was optimized this year, increasing the flexibility and efficiency of investors in hedging strategies and managing investment portfolios.

In 2024, Hong Kong's offshore RMB business saw steady growth. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority introduced optimized measures for the primary liquidity provider arrangement, including increasing the number of participating banks and expanding the scale of the arrangement. By the end of the year, the overnight cross-border service capacity of Hong Kong's RMB real-time payment settlement system was enhanced to better meet the global demand for cross-border RMB payments.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has introduced a number of measures benefiting the public and facilitating business under the Greater Bay Area financial cooperation framework, including a pilot program for cross-border credit information interoperability to promote cross-border financing for enterprises, as well as cross-border remittance payment arrangements to facilitate property purchases by Hong Kong residents in the Greater Bay Area.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to strive to enhance the competitiveness of Hong Kong's overall financial platform. Specifically, to enhance Hong Kong's appeal as a preferred fund management center and a hub for family office operations, the HKMA collaborates closely with the government and the financial sector to create a more favorable tax and regulatory environment. In addition, the HKMA issued a second batch of tokenized bonds through the Evergreen project and launched the "EvergreenHub" one-stop digital bond knowledge base and the "Digital Bond Grant Scheme" to continue driving innovation in Hong Kong's bond market. In October, the HKMA announced the "Sustainable Finance Action Agenda," outlining specific goals to further solidify Hong Kong's position as a regional hub for green and sustainable finance.

On the other hand, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to strengthen its market expansion efforts, introducing Hong Kong's financial services to overseas and mainland stakeholders. In November, the HKMA hosted the third "Global Financial Leaders’ Investment Summit." The three-day summit, themed "Navigating Through Change," brought together leading figures from the global financial industry to share their unique insights. The summit commenced with a keynote speech by Mr. He Lifeng, Vice Premier of the State Council, followed by sessions featuring three mainland financial regulatory authorities and panel discussions involving international financial leaders. Over 350 leaders from more than 120 international financial institutions participated in the summit, fully demonstrating the international financial community's support and confidence in Hong Kong.

During the year, the Financial Authority also held various other seminars and meetings, including:

- Co-hosted a joint climate finance conference with the Dubai Financial Services Authority in September;
- Co-hosted the 15th Global Risk Forum with the Global Association of Risk Professionals in October;
- Also co-hosted an international financial seminar with the Bank for International Settlements in October; and
- Held the Financial Stability Board plenary meeting in December, which was the first meeting of its kind in Asia since 2016, bringing together leaders and senior officials from over 50 national financial authorities and 12 international standard-setting bodies.

During the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) also actively strengthened its bilateral ties with other regions. In December, the HKMA held bilateral meetings in Hong Kong with the Central Bank of the United Arab Emirates (UAE Central Bank) and the Saudi Central Bank to promote investment and financial market linkages between the Middle East and Asia. The HKMA signed a memorandum of understanding with the UAE Central Bank to establish interoperability of debt capital market infrastructure between the two regions and to promote cross-border debt securities issuance and investment activities. Prior to this, in October, the HKMA visited Doha, Qatar, to strengthen cooperation in the financial services sector between the two regions.

In addition, the HKMA held the seventh Hong Kong-Switzerland financial cooperation dialogue in December, discussing topics covering regional and local prospects and policy challenges, as well as the latest developments and potential areas of cooperation in sustainable finance, financial technology, and market interconnectivity.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority visited Thailand and Malaysia in January and May respectively, meeting with central banks, financial institutions, and companies to promote Hong Kong's position as an international financial center and to further strengthen bilateral financial ties and cooperation. One of the key areas of focus was promoting the use of the renminbi and local currencies for cross-border investment and trade settlement, as well as highlighting Hong Kong's competitive advantages.

At the international level, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) actively participates in central banking matters and continues to play a leading role in various regional and international committees. The HKMA currently serves as co-chair of the Policy and Standards Group under the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (Basel Committee) and the Asia Regional Consultative Group under the Financial Stability Board, as well as co-chair of the Financial Innovation Network under the Financial Stability Board (until July 2024). The HKMA also chairs the Governors’ Meeting of Major Emerging Market Economies under the Bank for International Settlements and the Peer Review Group on the Crypto-Asset Framework under the Financial Stability Board. From 2018 to 2024, the HKMA has continuously served as chair of the Financial Markets Working Group under the East Asia and Pacific Central Bankers’ Meeting (EMEAP).

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Fintech Facilitation Office continues to implement the "Fintech 2025" strategy with various banking departments, promoting widespread adoption of fintech within the industry and enhancing Hong Kong's position as Asia's fintech hub. Key initiatives launched this year include:

Further promote the application of financial technology in five key areas by banks, including Wealthtech, Insurtech, Greentech, artificial intelligence, and distributed ledger technology.
Advance work on central bank digital currency to understand its benefits and potential use cases, including:
    - Progressing the mBridge project, a cross-border network for multiple central bank digital currencies, to improve cross-border payments;
    - Further studying the feasibility of issuing e-HKD in Hong Kong; and
    - Beginning to explore the use of central bank digital currency to support the development of Hong Kong’s tokenized market.
Facilitate lending for small and medium-sized enterprises through Commercial Data Interchange (CDI).
Strengthen cross-border fintech collaboration.
Promote broader use of the Faster Payment System (FPS).

The use of Faster Payment System continued to increase in 2024, with registration numbers and transaction volume steadily rising over the past six years. As of the end of 2024, the number of Faster Payment System registrations increased to 15.8 million, and the average daily transaction volume for the entire year rose by 33% compared to the previous year. In addition to steady growth in person-to-person payments and commercial payments, the continued increase in using Faster Payment System to pay government bills, make payments to merchants, and top up stored-value payment instruments such as e-wallets or bank accounts is a major driver of the continued growth in Faster Payment System transaction volume.

To ensure the safety and efficiency of local retail payment services, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority monitors six designated retail payment systems and regulates 15 licensed stored value facilities (four of which are issued by licensed banks) under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (the "Payment Ordinance"). Throughout the year, the Authority has continued to work closely with the industry, enhancing control measures and protecting consumers in response to the rising risk of fraud.

The Financial Secretary's Department and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) jointly released the consultation summary in July after completing a two-month public consultation in February on legislative proposals for establishing a regulatory framework for stablecoin issuers. The HKMA submitted the Stablecoins Bill to the Legislative Council for consideration in December. To better understand the business models of stablecoin issuers and develop appropriate regulatory measures, the HKMA also launched a stablecoin issuer "regulatory sandbox" and announced three participating institutions entering the sandbox in July. Meanwhile, the HKMA continues to actively participate in international organizations' work on digital assets-related issues (including stablecoins and tokenization), ensuring that the relevant regulatory framework aligns with international standards and best practices.

# The Hong Kong Monetary Authority released an overview of measures to enhance Hong Kong’s competitiveness as an international financial centre in 2024.

Deepen financial market connectivity between Hong Kong and the mainland, consolidate Hong Kong’s position as a hub for offshore RMB business, and strengthen connections within the Greater Bay Area.

Optimize the Cross-boundary Wealth Management Connect and Northbound Swap Connect.
Expand the eligible collateral for the HKMA's RMB liquidity arrangements and Northbound Swap Connect to include onshore RMB bonds issued by the Ministry of Finance and mainland policy banks.
Optimize the primary liquidity provider arrangement.
Enhance the nighttime cross-border service capability of Hong Kong's RMB real-time gross settlement system to better meet global demand for cross-border RMB payments.
Support the Shenzhen Municipal Government, Guangdong Provincial Government, and Hainan Provincial Government in issuing dim sum bonds in Hong Kong.
Facilitate cross-border financing for enterprises through cross-border credit information interoperability cooperation.
Implement streamlined cross-border remittance measures for property purchases in the Greater Bay Area.
Deepen exchanges and communication between relevant mainland institutions and the Hong Kong financial sector to explore business opportunities.

# Strengthening Connections with People Around the World

- Hosting a series of international events: "Global Financial Leaders’ Investment Summit," FSB Plenary Meeting, and seminars co-organized with the Bank for International Settlements  
- Strengthening market expansion efforts by promoting Hong Kong's financial services to overseas and mainland stakeholders, and laying a solid foundation for cooperation with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) region  
- Actively participating in international and regional central bank and regulatory organizations

# Enhance the competitiveness of financial platforms

- Drive innovation in the bond market through the Evergreen project, including assisting governments in issuing the world's first multi-currency digital bonds, launching the one-stop digital bond knowledge base "EvergreenHub," and introducing the "Digital Bond Grant Scheme"

zh:
# 儲備管理

2024年環球金融市場表現大致良好。主要經濟體錄得穩定增長，而通脹亦回落至更接近政策目標的水平。多個主要央行陸續下調政策利率，有利投資環境。2024年全年計，外匯基金錄得2,188億港元的投資收入，投資回報率為5.2%。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。金管局根據財政司司長轉授的權力及轉授權力的條款，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合架構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：

(i) 保障資本；
(ii) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(iii) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(iv) 在符合上述(i)至(iii)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障外匯基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合架構及目標資產配置中反映（圖示1）。

圖示1 外匯基金的投資組合類別

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員經濟體的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產配置於較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權（包括基建）及房地產。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的目標資產配置與其他資產類別的配置，按審慎的風險管理原則及資產組合多元化策略一起制定。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，一直持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎，但未來基金屬主要個別例子，其存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的回報掛鈎，利率視乎實際資產配置而定。於2024年，投資組合與長期增長組合在未來基金的目標資產配置約為35：65。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產配置及戰略性資產配置作基礎。策略性資產配置以投資基準方式反映，亦即外匯基金為達到投資目標而可作出的長線資產配置。外匯基金以策略性配置作為指引，透過戰略性的資產配置，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際配置往往會與基準配置（亦即策略性配置）有所偏離，而實際與基準配置之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及循跡誤差限額，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產配置及定出戰略性偏離的容許範圍。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的容許範圍內管理倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 直接投資

金管局的外匯基金投資辦公室專責外匯基金的投資及相關風險管理職能。該辦公室職員負責直接管理外匯基金約70%的投資，包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分內部管理的投資組合包括環球定息市場投資，並透過不同的衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約30%的資產，包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產類別。僱用外聘投資經理的目的是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資專才為外匯基金投資，獲取可持續回報，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化及互補的投資方式，以及汲取外聘投資經理的市場心得與專門的投資知識。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

# 風險管理及監察

投資環境越趨複雜，穩健的風險管理更見重要。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂下嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並設立嚴謹的風險監察及合規制度。金管局為投資相關活動設有三重防線，以實施有效的風險管理及管治。金管局定期監察主要投資風險類別（包括信用、市場、流動性及業務操作風險），並設置風險管理程序，為策略性規劃及多元化投資工作提供穩健的框架。

# 負責任投資

金管局相信適度強調負責任投資及投資的可持續長期表現，可更有效達致外匯基金的投資目標，並且減低投資活動涉及的環境、社會及管治(ESG)相關風險。為積極支持負責任投資，金管局已將ESG因素融入外匯基金的投資管理過程中，其指導性原則是：當ESG投資與其他投資項目的經風險調整長期收益相若時，一般會優先考慮ESG投資。有關金管局在負責任投資方面的工作，詳見《二零二四年可持續發展報告》之「負責任投資」一章。

# 外匯基金的表現

# 2024年的金融市場

2024年環球金融市場表現大致良好。

主要股票市場於2024年升幅顯著，當中美國股市在經濟和通脹基調大致向好和人工智能熱潮背景下，首三季升幅尤其突出。不過第4季市況因憂慮通脹升溫及債息上升等而變得波動並從高位回落，投資者亦轉趨審慎。內地和香港股市方面，受惠於中央在第3季出台的一系列刺激經濟和股市的政策措施，投資者信心有所好轉。然而市場認為實體經濟增長依然不明朗的情況下，兩地股市於第4季回軟。

環球債券市場在2024年的表現亦有較大波動。儘管主要央行大致確立減息的大方向，但減息的節奏和幅度年內出現多次轉變。及至第4季，市場開始注視美國2025年的財政政策，美國國債收益率季內大幅上升，債價受壓。

貨幣市場方面，美元兌其他主要貨幣於2024年，特別是第4季，因為息口走勢和美國經濟表現相對強勁而走強。

表1列載主要貨幣、債巿及股市在2024年的表現。

# 外匯基金的表現

外匯基金在2024年錄得2,188億港元的投資收入，其中包括：

- 債券投資收益1,359億港元；
- 股票投資收益909億港元（其中香港股票投資收益218億港元，其他股票的投資收益691億港元）；
- 非港元資產外匯估值下調356億港元；及
- 外匯基金投資控股附屬公司持有的其他投資收益276億港元。

另一方面，策略性資產組合錄得28億港元估值收益。

於2024年底，外匯基金的資產總值達40,810億港元。長期增長組合投資的總市值為5,412億港元，其中私募股權為4,348億港元，房地產為1,064億港元。長期增長組合中已承擔但尚未提取作投資的總額為2,886億港元。

外匯基金（不包括策略性資產組合）在2024年的投資回報率為5.2%，其中投資組合的回報率為7.2%，支持組合為4.1%。長期增長組合自2009年開展投資以來的年率化內部回報率為11.2%。

# Reserves Management

The global financial market performed reasonably well in 2024. Major economies recorded steady growth, and inflation also fell to levels closer to policy targets. Several major central banks successively lowered policy interest rates, which was beneficial to the investment environment. For the full year of 2024, the foreign exchange fund recorded investment income of HKD 218.8 billion, with a return on investment of 5.2%.

# Exchange Fund

According to the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary objective of the Exchange Fund is to influence the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar, directly or indirectly, and may also be used to maintain the stability and integrity of the monetary and financial system in Hong Kong, thereby maintaining Hong Kong’s position as an international financial centre. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is accountable to the Financial Secretary for the operation and investment management of the Exchange Fund, in accordance with the provisions delegating powers from the Financial Secretary and the delegation of authority.

# Foreign exchange fund management.

# Investment objectives and portfolio structure

The Foreign Exchange Fund Advisory Committee has formulated the following investment objectives for the Foreign Exchange Fund:

(i) Safeguarding capital;  
(ii) Ensuring that the overall monetary base is always fully supported by highly liquid U.S. dollar assets;  
(iii) Ensuring sufficient liquidity to maintain monetary and financial stability; and  
(iv) Striving to maximize investment returns, subject to the above (i) to (iii), in order to safeguard the long-term purchasing power of the foreign exchange fund.

The above objectives fully consider the statutory purposes of the foreign exchange fund and have been reflected in its portfolio structure and target asset allocation (Figure 1).

Figure 1 illustrates the categories of the foreign exchange fund’s investment portfolio.

The foreign exchange fund is broadly divided into two main portfolios: supporting portfolio and investment portfolio. The supporting portfolio holds highly liquid U.S. dollar assets, providing ample support for the currency base as stipulated by the currency issuance system. The investment portfolio primarily invests in bond and stock markets of member economies of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development to safeguard asset value and long-term purchasing power.

To more effectively manage risks and enhance long-term returns, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is gradually and prudently reallocating part of the Foreign Exchange Fund's assets into more diversified asset classes, including emerging market and mainland bonds and equities, private equity (including infrastructure) and real estate. Emerging market and mainland bonds and equities are held by the investment portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held by the long-term growth portfolio. The target asset allocation for the long-term growth portfolio, along with the allocation for other asset classes, is determined based on prudent risk management principles and a diversified asset allocation strategy.

The Strategic Asset Portfolio was established in 2007 and has consistently held shares of Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited purchased by the government for the Exchange Fund’s strategic purposes. Due to the unique nature of this portfolio, its performance is not included in the assessment of the Exchange Fund’s investment performance.

# Placements with the Exchange Fund

The Foreign Exchange Fund from time to time accepts deposits from fiscal reserves, government funds, and statutory organizations, with interest rates generally linked to the performance of the investment portfolio. However, the Future Fund serves as a key example, where deposit interest rates are tied to the returns of both the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio, with rates determined by the actual asset allocation. In 2024, the target asset allocation for the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio in the Future Fund was approximately 35:65.

# Investment Procedure

The investment process of the Exchange Fund is based on both strategic asset allocation and tactical asset allocation. Strategic asset allocation is reflected through an investment benchmark, which represents the long-term asset allocation that the Exchange Fund can make in pursuit of its investment objectives. The Exchange Fund uses strategic allocation as a guideline, and through tactical asset allocation, it aims to achieve returns that exceed the benchmark. Therefore, actual allocation often deviates from the benchmark allocation (i.e., the strategic allocation), and the difference between actual and benchmark allocation is referred to as "tactical deviations." The Financial Secretary sets the investment benchmark and tracking error limits after consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is authorized to determine the strategic asset allocation and set the allowable range of tactical deviations. Portfolio managers can manage the portfolio within the allowable range of tactical deviations to profit from short-term market fluctuations.

# Direct Investment

The Monetary Authority’s foreign exchange fund investment office is responsible for the investment and related risk management functions of the foreign exchange fund. The office’s staff are responsible for directly managing approximately 70% of the foreign exchange fund’s investments, including the entire supporting portfolio and part of the investment portfolio. This portion of internally managed investment portfolio includes investments in global fixed income markets, and executes the foreign exchange fund’s macroeconomic risk management strategies through various derivative instruments.

# External Fund Managers

In addition to managing assets through internal staff, the Financial Supervisory Commission also hires external investment managers to manage approximately 30% of the foreign exchange fund's assets, including all listed stock portfolios and other special asset categories. The purpose of hiring external investment managers is to leverage the best professional investment talent in the market for the foreign exchange fund's investments, obtain sustainable returns, and allow the foreign exchange fund to benefit from diversified and complementary investment approaches, as well as draw upon the external investment managers' market insights and specialized investment knowledge.

Expenses related to hiring an external investment manager include fund management and custody fees, transaction costs, withholding tax, and other taxes. These expenses are mainly influenced by market factors and vary each year.

# Risk Management and Supervision

The investment environment is becoming increasingly complex, making robust risk management even more critical. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has established strict control measures and investment guidelines for investment portfolios managed by both internal and external investment managers, and has set up a rigorous risk monitoring and compliance system. The HKMA has implemented a three-line defense system for investment-related activities to ensure effective risk management and governance. The HKMA regularly monitors major categories of investment risks (including credit, market, liquidity, and operational risks) and has established risk management procedures to provide a solid framework for strategic planning and diversified investment activities.

# Responsible Investment

The HKMA believes that appropriately emphasizing responsible investment and the sustainable long-term performance of investments can more effectively achieve the investment objectives of the HKMA's Investment Portfolio, and also reduce environmental, social, and governance (ESG) related risks associated with investment activities. To actively support responsible investment, the HKMA has integrated ESG factors into the investment management process of the HKMA's Investment Portfolio. Its guiding principle is that, when ESG investments yield risk-adjusted long-term returns comparable to other investment options, ESG investments are generally given priority. For details on the HKMA's work on responsible investment, please refer to the "Responsible Investment" chapter in the "Sustainability Report 2024".

# Foreign exchange fund performance

# The 2024 financial market.

The global financial market performance was generally positive in 2024.

Major stock markets saw significant gains in 2024, with the U.S. stock market performing particularly well in the first three quarters against a backdrop of generally positive economic and inflation trends and the AI boom. However, market conditions became volatile and retreated from their highs in the fourth quarter due to concerns about rising inflation and increasing bond yields, prompting investors to adopt a more cautious stance. Mainland China and Hong Kong stock markets benefited from a series of economic and stock market support measures introduced by the central government in the third quarter, which improved investor confidence. Nevertheless, with market participants still viewing the outlook for the real economy as uncertain, stock markets in both regions softened in the fourth quarter.

The global bond market experienced significant volatility in 2024. Despite major central banks largely establishing the direction of rate cuts, the pace and magnitude of these cuts shifted throughout the year. By the fourth quarter, the market began focusing on US fiscal policy for 2025, leading to a sharp rise in US Treasury yields and putting bond prices under pressure.

In the currency market, the US dollar strengthened against other major currencies in 2024, particularly in the fourth quarter, due to interest rate trends and the relatively strong performance of the US economy.

Table 1 shows the performance of major currencies, bond markets, and stock markets in 2024.

# Foreign exchange fund performance

The Hong Kong Foreign Exchange Fund recorded an investment income of HKD 218.8 billion in 2024, which includes:

- Bond investment gains of 13.59 billion Hong Kong dollars;  
- Stock investment gains of 9.09 billion Hong Kong dollars (of which 2.18 billion Hong Kong dollars from Hong Kong stock investments and 6.91 billion Hong Kong dollars from investments in other stocks);  
- A downward adjustment of 3.56 billion Hong Kong dollars in the foreign exchange valuation of non-Hong Kong dollar assets; and  
- Other investment gains of 2.76 billion Hong Kong dollars held by subsidiaries of the Exchange Fund Investment Holdings.

On the other hand, the strategic asset portfolio recorded valuation gains of 2.8 billion Hong Kong dollars.

By the end of 2024, the total assets of the Foreign Exchange Fund reached 40,810 billion HKD. The total market value of the long-term growth portfolio was 5,412 billion HKD, comprising 4,348 billion HKD in private equity and 1,064 billion HKD in real estate. The total amount committed but not yet drawn down for investment in the long-term growth portfolio was 2,886 billion HKD.

The Exchange Fund (excluding the strategic portfolio) achieved an investment return of 5.2% in 2024, with the investment portfolio returning 7.2% and the support portfolio returning 4.1%. The Long-Term Growth Portfolio has achieved an annualized internal rate of return of 11.2% since commencing investments in 2009.

Figure 1 shows the annual returns of the Foreign Exchange Fund from 1994 to 2024. Table 2 displays the investment returns of the Foreign Exchange Fund in 2024 and the average investment returns for different periods. The average return of the Foreign Exchange Fund from 2022 to 2024 was 2.0%, from 2020 to 2024 was 3.1%, from 2015 to 2024 was 3.1%, and since 1994 has been 4.5%. Table 3 lists the currency composition of the Foreign Exchange Fund's assets as of December 31, 2024. For details, refer to the audited 2024 annual financial statements of the Foreign Exchange Fund on pages 203 to 309.

Figure 1: Foreign Exchange Fund Investment Return Rate (1994–2024)

zh:
# 機構職能

機構職能部門支持金管局的運作，保持高透明度與問責性，並發揮卓越的效率及專業水準。為促進公眾對金管局的政策及工作的了解，金管局透過傳統及社交媒體、金管局網站、金管局資訊中心及其他渠道積極與整體社會及市場參與者保持聯繫。

對內方面，金管局致力建立一支靈活應變及專業的工作團隊，同時遵守嚴格的財政紀律及提升數碼能力，應對變化及確保有效執行各項政策及措施。

# 保持透明度

# 傳媒關係及社交媒體應用

金管局與傳媒保持緊密聯繫，以提高透明度及增進公眾對其政策及運作的了解。金管局在2024年共舉辦或參與207次活動，包括14次新聞發布會、四次傳媒簡報會、14次即場訪問及175次其他公開活動。為增進社會對金管局主要職能的認識，金管局為本地、內地及境外的媒體舉辦新聞發布會及傳媒簡報會，涵蓋代幣化、防騙措施及支援中小企措施等主題。年內金管局亦安排25次媒體訪談、發布約600份雙語新聞稿，並處理大量傳媒日常查詢。

總裁余偉文先生於「香港金融科技周2024」接受媒體即場訪問

副總裁李達志先生於「戶口互聯」用例展示日致歡迎辭

傳媒代表積極參與金管局在2024年舉辦的活動，尤其是第三屆「國際金融領袖投資峰會」。峰會為期三日，獲得本地、內地及國際媒體逾萬篇新聞報道。

總裁余偉文先生於「國際金融領袖投資峰會2024」接受媒體直播訪問

副總裁阮國恒先生就成立「中小企融資專責小組」主持傳媒簡報會

副總裁陳維民先生於「2024財資市場高峰會」上致開幕辭

為更有效聯繫公眾，金管局共營運六個社交媒體專頁（包括Facebook、Instagram、LinkedIn、WeChat、X（前稱Twitter）及YouTube），獲超過200,000名用戶關注。金管局製作富創意的社交媒體內容，提高公眾對一系列議題及舉措的認識，例如防騙、金融科技、綠色和可持續金融、支援中小企及金管局舉辦的大型盛事等。金管局亦在其社交媒體專頁直播「國際金融領袖投資峰會」，促進公眾及業界參與。

在社交媒體發布創意內容，有助增加公眾對金管局舉措及各類議題的認識

# 公眾查詢

金管局的公眾查詢服務為市民提供有效渠道，以增進其對金管局主要職能及運作的認識。

在2024年公眾查詢服務共處理9,594宗查詢（圖1），全部都在金管局服務承諾時限內回覆（表1）。這些查詢中約有一半涉及銀行消費者事宜、金融基建與債券市場發展、銀行業政策及規例，以及紙幣與硬幣（圖2）。常見的查詢包括硬幣收集計劃、銀行產品及服務、零售債券發行計劃、銀行業相關指引與通告，以及「轉數快」。

圖 1 公眾查詢總數

圖 2 按性質列出2024年接獲的查詢

# 刊物

年內金管局出版《二零二三年年報》及《二零二三年可持續發展報告》。《二零二三年可持續發展報告》在香港會計師公會「最佳企業管治及ESG大獎2024」的「公眾/非牟利機構（大型）」類別中獲得評判嘉許獎。此外，《二零二三年年報》在香港管理專業協會2024年度最佳年報評選中獲得「非牟利及慈善機構」類銅獎。

在2024年，金管局定期更新《金融數據月報》1資料，並出版：

- 兩期《貨幣與金融穩定情況半年度報告》
- 四期《季報》；及
- 14篇《匯思》文章。

# 機構網站

機構網站(www.hkma.gov.hk)提供73,000多頁英文版及繁簡字體中文版資料，方便公眾查閱金管局的最新資訊。網站亦載有根據《銀行業條例》第20條備存的「認可機構及本地代表辦事處紀錄冊」及「認可機構證券業務員工紀錄冊」，以及根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》備存的「儲值支付工具持牌人紀錄冊」。

金管局自2018年起透過開放應用程式介面（開放API），分階段發放在其網站所載的金融數據及重要資訊。截至2024年底，我們按照原定計劃在網站推出合共177組開放API。有關金管局開放API的更詳盡資料，請瀏覽金管局開放API門戶網站(https://apidocs.hkma.gov.hk)。

# 資訊中心

金管局資訊中心設於國際金融中心2期55樓，分為展覽館及圖書館兩部分，旨在向公眾介紹金管局的工作，並提高公眾對貨幣與銀行業事宜的認識。展覽館以互動方式簡介金管局的工作，以及香港貨幣與銀行業的發展；另備資料與展品，供研究香港貨幣、銀行業與金融事務。

年內資訊中心接待超過68,000名訪客，較2023年增加約120%。資訊中心亦為學校及其他團體提供570多次導賞服務。

毗鄰展覽館的圖書館收藏超過26,000冊書籍、期刊及其他刊物，涵蓋香港貨幣、銀行業、金融和中央銀行事務等課題。圖書館亦備存《銀行業條例》第20條規定的「認可機構及本地代表辦事處紀錄冊」及「認可機構證券業務員工紀錄冊」，供公眾查閱。

幼稚園生參加資訊中心導賞，認識有關香港鈔票的設計

資訊中心人員向訪客介紹以香港硬幣砌出維港景色的馬賽克作品

# 社區聯繫及公眾教育

為增進市民對金管局工作的認識，金管局自1998年起推出公眾教育講座，至今錄得參加者人數超過68,000名。於2024年，我們舉行網上講座，吸引800多名來自41間中學的師生參加。講座內容涵蓋金管局工作簡介、聯繫匯率制度、香港鈔票、防騙、存款保障計劃、綠色金融及銀行業發展機遇。

我們使用不同渠道聯繫及教育公眾，提醒他們如何做個精明及負責任的金融服務消費者。2024年的活動合共吸引超過67,000名市民參與。

為配合數碼支付及綠色生活的趨勢，我們透過社交媒體及電台宣傳，鼓勵市民於農曆新年期間派發電子利是，亦可考慮以「迎新鈔」派發實體利是。

製作動畫短片鼓勵派發電子利是

# 防騙歌曲 — 《Link咪亂撳》

為進一步加強防騙工作，我們推出由歌手尹光先生與金管局副總裁阮國恒先生合唱的防騙歌曲，提醒市民「假Link咪當真，唔好俾人昆」，以及要妥善保管敏感的個人資料與信用卡資料。跨媒體宣傳活動的成效得到肯定，取得國際推廣殊榮。

副總裁阮國恒先生（右）參與演繹防騙歌曲

跨媒體宣傳活動加強公眾防騙意識

# 《跨境理財新機遇》電視短片系列

金管局與一間本地電視台聯合製作《跨境理財新機遇》電視短片系列，協助市民進一步了解「粵港澳大灣區跨境理財通」（「跨境理財通」）為零售投資者在跨境投資上帶來的機遇及便利。這短片系列藉五部膾炙人口的港產電影的「經典場面」，解說「跨境理財通」的框架、投資者的資格要求、「北向通」與「南向通」提供的產品、風險管理，以及跨境投資應注意的事項，並透過電視、數碼及社交媒體平台進行推廣。

短片以風趣幽默的方式介紹「跨境理財通」

# 全港理財爭霸戰

為提高中學生的理財知識，金管局與多個相關機構合作舉辦「全港理財爭霸戰」。該活動在2024年踏入十周年，主題為「未來金融人才」，旨在讓中學生及早認識創新、金融科技、人工智能等發展及未來動向，以及推動學生秉持可持續發展與環境、社會及管治原則。

爭霸戰第一部分是網上問答比賽，測試參賽學生的理財知識及對熱門金融課題的認識。於2024年，來自290所中學共32,000人次參與網上問答比賽，創下歷年新高。在2015年至2024年間，來自440所中學的學生參與爭霸戰的網上問答比賽環節共約125,000次。爭霸戰的第二部分「少年金融人才計劃」以師友形式進行，由不同範疇的資深從業員擔任導師，培訓學生準備參與「設計思維挑戰賽」。在2024年，這部分的爭霸戰更特別增設「大灣區邀請賽」，以促進粵港澳三地學生互動交流。

副總裁陳維民先生在爭霸戰總決賽致歡迎辭，並為總決賽參賽者打氣

參與「少年金融人才計劃」的學生與導師會面

# 桌上教育遊戲

金管局在2023年推出其首個理財教育桌上遊戲《$mart理財321》，並於2024年繼續推廣，讓更多人認識這副原創桌遊，並加強其作為教育工具的用途，讓小學生在模擬情景下認識不同的支付方法、基本理財概念、金融科技及網絡安全。

在社區層面，我們於「香港書展2024」設置攤位，並在聖誕節及農曆新年期間於社區舉辧工作坊，以及在金管局辦事處舉辦親子工作坊，進一步推廣金融及理財概念。此外，我們亦安排到校活動讓小學生試玩，並舉辦培訓工作坊，鼓勵中學教師在新設初中科目「公民、經濟與社會」的理財教育單元中使用桌遊作為教材之一。桌遊得到教育局肯定為出色的教學工具之一，並用作其舉辦的「理財教育學校獎勵計劃」（2023/24）優勝學校的獎品。金管局在2024年合共舉辧約40場桌遊工作坊，獲得超過3,600名學生、家長、教師及社工參與。

在開發《$mart理財321》桌遊的經驗基礎上，金管局推出策略桌遊《企業綠化大變身》，於「香港書展2024」的攤位作為紀念品送出。這是全港首副向學生傳遞綠色金融知識的桌遊。

此外，我們繼續支持投資者及理財教育委員會的工作，提升香港市民的金融知識及理財能力，並會研究與不同持份者進一步合作，提高社區參與工作的成效。

透過桌遊活動向教師、學童及家長推廣理財教育

# 財務披露

為維持高透明度，金管局採納適用於中央銀行運作的國際財務披露標準，包括香港財務報告準則及國際貨幣基金組織的數據公布特殊標準。財務處在獨立審計師及其他會計專業人員協助下，按照香港財務報告準則編製外匯基金財務報表。此外，金管局在《年報》詳細披露及深入分析預算及支出資料（請參閱第193至194頁「預算編製及財務管控」一節）。

en:
# Corporate Functions

The organization's functional departments support the operation of the HKMA, maintaining a high degree of transparency and accountability, and demonstrating outstanding efficiency and professionalism. To promote public understanding of the HKMA’s policies and work, the HKMA actively engages with the wider community and market participants through traditional and social media, the HKMA website, the HKMA Information Centre and other channels.

In terms of internal matters, the Monetary Authority is committed to establishing a flexible and professional work team, while adhering to strict fiscal discipline and enhancing digital capabilities to respond to changes and ensure the effective implementation of various policies and measures.

# Maintain transparency

# Media Relations and Social Media Applications

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority maintains close communication with the media to enhance transparency and promote public understanding of its policies and operations. In 2024, the HKMA organized or participated in a total of 207 events, including 14 press conferences, four media briefings, 14 on-site interviews, and 175 other public events. To enhance public awareness of the HKMA’s key functions, the HKMA held press conferences and media briefings for local, mainland, and overseas media, covering topics such as tokenization, anti-fraud measures, and support measures for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Throughout the year, the HKMA also arranged 25 media interviews, issued approximately 600 bilingual press releases, and handled a large number of routine media inquiries.

President Yu Wai Man was interviewed live by the media at “Hong Kong FinTech Week 2024”.

Vice President Mr. Li Dazhi delivered a welcome speech at the Household Registration Interconnection Use Case Demonstration Day.

Media representatives actively participated in the activities hosted by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority in 2024, particularly the third Global Financial Leaders’ Investment Summit. The summit lasted three days and garnered over ten thousand news reports from local, mainland, and international media.

Chairman Yu Weiwen was interviewed live by the media at the "International Financial Leaders Investment Summit 2024."

Mr. Guo-Heng Ruan, Vice President, chaired a media briefing session on the establishment of the "Taskforce on SME Lending"

Mr. Chen Weimin, Deputy President, delivered the opening remarks at the "2024 Capital Markets Summit".

To better connect with the public, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) operates six social media pages (including Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, WeChat, X (formerly Twitter), and YouTube), which have attracted over 200,000 followers. The HKMA creates creative social media content to raise public awareness of a range of topics and initiatives, such as fraud prevention, fintech, green and sustainable finance, support for small and medium-sized enterprises, and major events organized by the HKMA. The HKMA also live-streams the Global Financial Leaders’ Investment Summit on its social media pages, promoting public and industry participation.

Sharing creative content on social media can help increase public awareness of the Monetary Authority’s measures and various issues.

# Public Inquiry

The public inquiry service of the Monetary Authority provides citizens with an effective channel to enhance their understanding of the Monetary Authority's main functions and operations.

In 2024, the public inquiry service handled a total of 9,594 inquiries (Figure 1), all of which were responded to within the HKMA's service commitment timeframe (Table 1). Approximately half of these inquiries involved banking consumer matters, financial infrastructure and bond market development, banking policies and regulations, as well as paper currency and coins (Figure 2). Common inquiries included the coin collection program, banking products and services, the Retail Bond Issuance Programme, banking-related guidelines and circulars, and the Faster Payment System.

Figure 1: Total Number of Public Inquiries

Figure 2: 2024 Queries Received Classified by Type

# Publication

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority published its “2023 Annual Report” and “2023 Sustainability Report” this year. The “2023 Sustainability Report” received a Judges' Commendation Award in the “Public/Non-profit Organizations (Large)” category of the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants’ “Best Corporate Governance and ESG Awards 2024.” In addition, the “2023 Annual Report” won a Bronze Award in the “Non-profit and Charitable Organizations” category of the Hong Kong Management Association’s 2024 Annual Report Awards.

In 2024, the Monetary Authority regularly updated the "Monthly Statistical Bulletin"1 and published:

- Two issues of the Half-Yearly Monetary and Financial Stability Report  
- Four issues of the Quarterly Bulletin; and  
- 14 articles from the Insight publication.

# Institutional Website

The HKMA website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides over 73,000 pages of information in English, as well as in traditional and simplified Chinese, making it convenient for the public to access the latest information from the HKMA. The website also hosts the "Register of Recognized Institutions and Local Representative Offices" and the "Register of Securities Staff of AIs" maintained under section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the "Register of Licensed Stored Value Facility Operators" maintained under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has been gradually releasing financial data and important information on its website through open application programming interfaces (open APIs) since 2018. As of the end of 2024, we have launched a total of 177 sets of open APIs on the website in accordance with the original plan. For more detailed information on the HKMA's open APIs, please visit the HKMA Open API Portal Website (https://apidocs.hkma.gov.hk).

# Information Center

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Information Centre is located on the 55th floor of Phase 2 of the International Finance Centre and comprises an exhibition hall and a library. It aims to introduce the Authority's work to the public and enhance public understanding of monetary and banking issues. The exhibition hall provides an interactive introduction to the HKMA's work and the development of Hong Kong's monetary and banking sector, and also provides data and exhibits for research on Hong Kong currency, banking, and financial affairs.

The Information Center welcomed over 68,000 visitors this year, an increase of about 120% compared to 2023. The Information Center also provided more than 570 guided tours for schools and other groups.

The library adjacent to the exhibition hall houses over 26,000 books, journals, and other publications covering topics such as Hong Kong currency, banking, finance, and central banking. The library also maintains the “register of recognized institutions and local representative offices” and the “register of securities staff of AIs,” as stipulated in Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, available for public reference.

Kindergarten students participate in a guided tour at the information center to learn about the design of Hong Kong banknotes.

Information center staff introduce visitors to a mosaic artwork made with Hong Kong coins depicting the scenery of Victoria Harbour.

# Community engagement and public education

To enhance public understanding of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's (HKMA) work, the HKMA has been organizing public education seminars since 1998. To date, the number of participants has exceeded 68,000. In 2024, we held an online seminar that attracted more than 800 students and teachers from 41 secondary schools. The seminar covered topics including an introduction to the HKMA's work, the Linked Exchange Rate System, Hong Kong banknotes, fraud prevention, the Deposit Protection Scheme, green finance, and opportunities in the banking industry.

We use various channels to communicate with and educate the public, reminding them how to be smart and responsible financial services consumers. The activities in 2024 attracted over 67,000 citizens in total.

To align with the trends of digital payments and a green lifestyle, we are promoting through social media and radio, encouraging citizens to give out electronic red envelopes during the Lunar New Year period, and also considering distributing physical red envelopes in the form of "good-as-new banknotes."

Producing animated short films encourages the distribution of electronic red envelopes

# Scam Prevention Song — "Don't Press Link"

To further strengthen anti-fraud efforts, we have launched an anti-fraud song performed by singer Mr. Yin Guang and Mr. Ruan Guo Heng, Deputy Governor of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, reminding citizens "Don't take fake links as genuine, don't give personal information to others," and to properly safeguard sensitive personal data and credit card information. The effectiveness of the cross-media publicity campaign has been recognized, earning international accolades.

Vice President Nguyen Quoc Hung (right) participated in performing the anti-fraud song.

Cross-media promotional activities strengthen public anti-fraud awareness.

# "New Opportunities in Cross-border Wealth Management" TV Short Series

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has partnered with a local television station to produce a series of television shorts titled “New Opportunities in Cross-boundary Wealth Management,” aiming to help the public better understand the opportunities and convenience offered by the Cross-boundary Wealth Management Connect Scheme (WMC) for retail investors in cross-border investment. This series explains the framework of the WMC, investor eligibility requirements, products offered under the Northbound Scheme and Southbound Scheme, risk management, and important considerations for cross-border investment, using iconic moments from five popular Hong Kong films. The shorts will be promoted through television, digital, and social media platforms.

The short video introduces “Wealth Management Connect” in a witty and humorous manner.

# Hong Kong Financial Literacy Championship

To enhance secondary students' financial literacy, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) collaborates with various relevant organizations to host the "Hong Kong Financial Literacy Championship." In 2024, the event marks its 10th anniversary, with the theme "Next-gen Finance." The initiative aims to help secondary students gain early insights into innovations, fintech, artificial intelligence, and future trends, while encouraging students to uphold sustainable development and environmental, social, and governance principles.

The first part of the Clash of Champions is an online quiz competition, testing participants' financial knowledge and understanding of popular financial topics. In 2024, 32,000 participants from 290 schools took part in the online quiz, setting a new record. From 2015 to 2024, students from 440 schools participated in the online quiz segment of the Clash of Champions approximately 125,000 times. The second part of the Clash of Champions, the "Young Financial Talent Runway," is conducted in a mentorship format, with senior professionals from various fields serving as mentors to train students for the "Design Thinking Challenge." In 2024, this part of the Clash of Champions specially added the "GBA Invitation Match" to promote interaction and exchange among students from Guangdong, Hong Kong, and Macau.

Vice President Chen Weimin delivered a welcoming speech at the championship final and encouraged the finalists.

Students participating in the Young Financial Talent Runway will meet with mentors.

# Tabletop educational games

In 2023, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority launched its first financial education board game, “$mart Finance 321,” and continued to promote it in 2024 to allow more people to become familiar with this original board game and enhance its use as an educational tool, enabling primary school students to learn about different payment methods, basic financial concepts, financial technology, and cybersecurity in simulated scenarios.

At the community level, we set up a booth at the "Hong Kong Book Fair 2024," and held workshops during the Christmas and Lunar New Year periods in the community, as well as parent-child workshops at the HKMA office, further promoting financial and money management concepts. In addition, we arranged school visits for primary students to try out the board games, and conducted training workshops to encourage secondary school teachers to use board games as one of the teaching materials in the financial education module of the newly introduced secondary school subject "Citizenship, Economics and Society." The board games have been recognized by the Education Bureau as one of the outstanding teaching tools and were used as prizes for the winning schools in its "Financial Education School Award Scheme" (2023/24). In 2024, the HKMA held a total of about 40 board game workshops, attracting participation from over 3,600 students, parents, teachers, and social workers.

Following the development of the "$mart Wealth Management 321" board game, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority launched the strategy board game "Corporate Green Transformation" as a souvenir giveaway at its booth during the "Hong Kong Book Fair 2024." This is Hong Kong's first board game designed to educate students about green finance.

In addition, we continue to support the work of the Investor and Financial Education Council to enhance the financial knowledge and wealth management capabilities of Hong Kong residents, and will explore further collaboration with different stakeholders to improve the effectiveness of community engagement initiatives.

Promote financial literacy to teachers, students, and parents through board game activities.

# financial disclosure

To maintain a high level of transparency, the HKMA adopts international financial disclosure standards applicable to central bank operations, including Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards and the International Monetary Fund’s Special Data Dissemination Standard. The Financial Division prepares the Exchange Fund financial statements in accordance with Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards with the assistance of independent auditors and other accounting professionals. In addition, the HKMA discloses and thoroughly analyzes budgetary and expenditure information in detail in its Annual Report (please refer to the section “Budgeting and Financial Control” on pages 193 to 194).

# 外匯基金

- 審計署署長報告
- 外匯基金財務報表

# 審計署署長報告

# 香港特別行政區政府審璚計毐署

# 獨立審計師報告致財政司司長

# 意見

茲證明我已審計列載於第209至309頁外匯基金及其附屬公司（「集團」）的財務報表，該等財務報表包括外匯基金及集團於2024年12月31日的資產負債表與截至該日止年度的收支帳目、全面收益表、權益變動表和現金流量表，以及財務報表的附註，包括重大會計政策資料。

我認為，該等財務報表已按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告會計準則》真實而中肯地反映外匯基金及集團於2024年12月31日的財務狀況及截至該日止年度的財務表現和現金流量，並已按照行政長官在《外匯基金條例》（第66章）第7條下所發出的指示妥為擬備。

# 意見的基礎

我已按照行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示及審計署的審計準則進行審計。我根據該等準則而須承擔的責任，詳載於本報告「審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任」部分。根據該等準則，我獨立於集團，並已按該等準則履行其他道德責任。我相信，我所獲得的審計憑證是充足和適當地為我的審計意見提供基礎。

# 關鍵審計事項

關鍵審計事項是根據我的專業判斷，對截至2024年12月31日止年度財務報表的審計最為重要的事項。我對整體財務報表進行審計及形成意見時處理了這些事項，而我不會對這些事項提供單獨的意見。

# 按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值

請參閱財務報表附註2.5、2.6及37.1。

於2024年12月31日，集團按公平值列帳的金融資產共 39,151.17 億港元，金融負債共 13,862.99 億港元。

86%的該等金融資產及所有該等金融負債的公平值為相同資產或負債於活躍市場的報價（第1級參數），或是以估值方法估計，而所用的參數是以可觀察市場數據為基礎（第2級參數）。

其餘14%的該等金融資產的公平值，是以估值方法估計，而所用的參數並非以可觀察市場數據為基礎（第3級參數）。有關金融資產共5,522.51億港元，主要包括非上市投資基金。

鑑於所涉數額龐大及涉及估計，按公平值列帳的金 融資產及金融負債的估值屬關鍵審計事項。

就按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值，審計程序包括：

- 了解不同類別金融資產及金融負債的估值程序，包括相關監控措施；

- 評價及測試監控措施，包括電腦系統的相關應用程式監控措施；

- 就金融資產及金融負債的估值、存在、權利與責任及完整性取得函證；

- 若使用市場報價，根據獨立來源核實價格；

- 若所用估值方法的參數是以可觀察市場數據為基礎，評價估值方法是否適合及有關假設是否合理，以及根據獨立來源核實參數；及

- 若所用估值方法的參數並非以可觀察市場數據為基礎，評價估值方法是否適合，以及有關假設與參數是否合理。

# 按公平值列帳的投資物業的估值

請參閱財務報表附註2.11、17及18。

集團的投資物業按公平值列帳，於2024年12月31日共值211.32億港元。集團亦於聯營公司及合營公司擁有權益，該等公司主要業務為持有海外投資物業。不論是由集團直接持有或由聯營公司或合營公司持有，該等投資物業的公平值均主要根據獨立專業估值師的估值釐定。該等估值涉及重大判斷及估計，包括所用的估值方法及假設。

就按公平值列帳的投資物業的估值，審計程序包括：

- 獲取及審視由集團直接持有或由聯營公司或合營公司持有的投資物業的估值報告，並核實公平值是根據有關估值報告所列的估值釐定；

- 評估估值師的獨立性及資歷；及

- 評價估值方法是否適合，以及有關假設與參數是否合理。

# 其他資料

金融管理專員須對其他資料負責。其他資料包括金融管理局2024年年報內的所有資料，但不包括財務報表及我的審計師報告。

我對財務報表的意見並不涵蓋其他資料，我亦不對其他資料發表任何形式的鑒證結論。

就財務報表審計而言，我有責任閱讀其他資料，從而考慮其他資料是否與財務報表或我在審計過程中得悉的情況有重大矛盾，或者似乎存有重大錯誤陳述。基於我已執行的工作，如果我認為其他資料存有重大錯誤陳述，我需要報告該事實。在這方面，我沒有任何報告。

# 金融管理專員及外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會就財務報表而須承擔的責任

金融管理專員須負責按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告會計準則》及行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示擬備真實而中肯的財務報表，及落實其認為必要的內部控制， 使財務報表不存有因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述。

在擬備財務報表時，金融管理專員須負責評估集團持續經營的能力，以及在適用情況下披露與持續經營有關的事項，並以持續經營作為會計基礎。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會負責監督集團的財務報告過程。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：

- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；

- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；

- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；

- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；

- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否中肯反映交易和事項；及

-計劃並執行集團審計，以就集團中實體或業務單位的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，作為對財務報表形成意見的基礎。我負責指導、監督和審視為進行集團審計而履行的審計工作。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

我亦會向外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會提交聲明，說明我已符合有關獨立性的相關道德要求，並與他們溝通所有被合理認為可能會影響我獨立性的關係和其他事項，以及在適用的情況下，相關的防範措施。

從與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通的事項中，我會決定哪些事項對本期財務報表的審計最為重要，因而構成關鍵審計事項。我會在審計師報告中描述這些事項，除非法律法規不允許對某件事項作出公開披露，或在極端罕見的情況下，因為有合理預期在我報告中溝通某事項而造成的負面後果將會超過其產生的公眾利益而我決定不應在報告中溝通該事項。

# 外匯基金 – 財務報表附註

（除特別註明外，所有金額均以港幣百萬元位列示。）

# 1 主要業務

金融管理專員根據財政司司長以外匯基金（基金）管理人身分授予的權力，按照《外匯基金條例》（第66章）的條文管理基金。基金的主要業務為捍衛港元匯率及維持香港貨幣及金融體系的穩定健全。

基金的資產分作四個不同的組合來管理：支持組合、投資組合、長期增長組合及策略性資產組合。根據香港的貨幣發行局制度，支持組合的資產與貨幣基礎完全相配。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員國的債券及股票市場。長期增長組合持有私募股權及房地產投資。策略性資產組合持有香港特別行政區（香港特區）政府為策略目的而購入，並列入基金的帳目內的香港交易及結算所有限公司的股票。經營分部資料載於附註31。

# Exchange Fund

- Report by the Comptroller and Auditor General  
- Financial Statements of the Foreign Exchange Fund

# Report by the Audit Office Director

# Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government Audit Commission

# Independent Auditor's Report to the Financial Secretary

# Opinion

This certificate confirms that I have audited the financial statements of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and its subsidiaries ("the Group") listed in pages 209 to 309. These financial statements include the balance sheets of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Group as at December 31, 2024, the income statements, statements of comprehensive income, statements of changes in equity, cash flow statements, and the notes to the financial statements, including significant accounting policy information for the period ended on that date.

I believe that the financial statements have been prepared in accordance with the HKFRS Accounting Standards and have truly and fairly reflected the financial position of the Exchange Fund and the Group as at December 31, 2024, and the results of operations and cash flows for the year ended on that date, and have been properly prepared in accordance with the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance (Cap. 66).

# The basis of opinion.

I have conducted the audit in accordance with the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under Section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance and the auditing standards of the Audit Department. The responsibilities I am required to bear under these standards are set out in this report's section "Responsibilities of the Auditor in Relation to the Audit of Financial Statements." Under these standards, I am independent of the group and have fulfilled other ethical responsibilities in accordance with these standards. I believe that the audit evidence I have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for my audit opinion.

# Key audit matters

Key audit matters are those matters that, in my professional judgment, are of most importance to the audit of the financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2024. I addressed these matters in the course of my audit of, and in forming my opinion on, the financial statements as a whole, and I do not provide a separate opinion on these matters.

# Valuation of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities Measured at Fair Value

Please refer to financial statement notes 2.5, 2.6, and 37.1.

As of December 31, 2024, the Group’s financial assets measured at fair value totaled HK$39,151.17 billion, and financial liabilities totaled HK$13,862.99 billion.

The fair value of 86% of these financial assets and all of these financial liabilities is based on quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets (Level 1 inputs), or estimated using valuation methods where the parameters used are based on observable market data (Level 2 inputs).

The fair value of the remaining 14% of such financial assets is estimated using valuation techniques, and the parameters used are not based on observable market data (Level 3 inputs). The total amount of such financial assets is HKD 55,225.1 million, mainly consisting of unlisted investment funds.

Given the significant amounts involved and the use of estimates, the valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value is a key audit matter.

The audit procedures for the valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value include:

Understand the valuation procedures for different categories of financial assets and financial liabilities, including related monitoring measures;

Evaluation and testing of monitoring measures, including monitoring measures for related applications in computer systems;

Obtain confirmations regarding the valuation, existence, rights and obligations, and completeness of financial assets and financial liabilities;

If market quotations are used, the prices should be verified by independent sources.

If the parameters used in the valuation method are based on observable market data, evaluate whether the valuation method is appropriate and whether the related assumptions are reasonable, and verify the parameters using independent sources; and

If the parameters used in the valuation method are not based on observable market data, assess the suitability of the valuation method and the reasonableness of the related assumptions and parameters.

# Valuation of Investment Properties Measured at Fair Value

Please refer to Notes 2.11, 17, and 18 of the financial statements.

The Group's investment properties are accounted for at fair value, totaling HK$21,132 million as of December 31, 2024. The Group also holds interests in joint ventures and associate companies, which mainly engage in holding overseas investment properties. The fair values of these investment properties, whether directly held by the Group or by joint ventures or associate companies, are primarily determined by independent professional valuers. These valuations involve significant judgments and estimates, including the valuation methods and assumptions used.

Regarding the valuation of investment property accounted for at fair value, audit procedures include:

- Obtain and review valuation reports of investment properties directly held by the Group or held by associate companies or joint ventures, and verify that the fair value is determined based on the valuations listed in the relevant valuation reports;

Assess the independence and qualifications of the appraiser; and

Evaluate whether the valuation method is appropriate and whether the assumptions and parameters are reasonable.

# Other materials

The Financial Controller is responsible for other information. This other information includes all information in the 2024 Annual Report of the Financial Services Commission, except for the financial statements and my auditor's report.

My opinion on the financial statements does not extend to other information, and I also do not express any form of attestation conclusion regarding other information.

With respect to the audit of financial statements, I have a responsibility to read other information, in order to consider whether such information is materially inconsistent with the financial statements or with circumstances known to me during the audit process, or appears to contain material misstatements. Based on the work I have performed, if I conclude that other information contains material misstatements, I need to report that fact. In this regard, I have nothing to report.

# Responsibilities of the financial controller and the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee with respect to financial statements.

The Financial Management Officer must be responsible for preparing financial statements that are true and fair in accordance with the HKFRS Accounting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Accountants and the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance, and implementing the internal controls that the Financial Management Officer considers necessary to ensure that the financial statements do not contain material misstatements due to fraud or error.

When preparing financial statements, the financial manager must be responsible for assessing the group's ability to continue as a going concern, and disclose matters related to going concern when applicable, using the going concern as the accounting basis.

The Audit Committee under the Foreign Exchange Fund Advisory Committee is responsible for overseeing the Group’s financial reporting process.

# Auditors bear responsibilities regarding the audit of financial statements.

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance that the financial statements as a whole do not contain any material misstatements resulting from fraud or error, and to issue an auditor's report that includes my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but it does not guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with the audit standards of the audit office will necessarily detect any material misstatements that may exist. A misstatement may be caused by fraud or error, and it is considered material if it is reasonably expected that it, individually or in aggregate, could influence the economic decisions made by users of the financial statements.

During the process of conducting an audit in accordance with the audit standards of the audit office, I will exercise professional judgment and maintain a professional skeptical attitude. I will also:

Identify and assess the risks of material misstatements in the financial statements resulting from fraud or error; design and perform audit procedures to respond to these risks; and obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence to support my opinion. Since fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, false statements, or overriding internal controls, the risk of failing to detect material misstatements caused by fraud is higher than the risk of failing to detect those caused by error.

Understand the internal controls related to auditing in order to design appropriate audit procedures. However, this is not intended to express an opinion on the effectiveness of the group’s internal controls.

Evaluate whether the accounting policies adopted by the financial management officer are appropriate, and whether the accounting estimates made and related disclosures are reasonable.

Determine whether the Financial Manager's use of the going concern basis of accounting is appropriate, and based on the audit evidence obtained, assess whether there are material uncertainties related to events or circumstances that may cast significant doubt on the Group's ability to continue as a going concern. If I conclude that material uncertainties exist, it is necessary for the auditor's report to draw the attention of users to the related disclosures in the financial statements. If the disclosed information is insufficient, I must issue a non-unqualified auditor's report. My conclusion is based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of the auditor's report. However, future events or circumstances may result in the Group being unable to continue as a going concern;

Evaluate the overall presentation, structure, and content of the financial statements, including disclosures, and whether the financial statements fairly reflect the transactions and events; and

Plan and perform a group audit to obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence for the financial information of entities or business units within the group, as a basis for forming an opinion on the financial statements. I am responsible for directing, supervising, and reviewing the audit work performed to carry out the group audit. I take full responsibility for my audit opinion.

I will communicate with the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding the scope and timeline of the plan’s audit, as well as significant audit findings, including any material deficiencies in internal control that I identify during the audit.

I will also submit a statement to the Audit Committee under the Foreign Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, stating that I have met the relevant ethical requirements regarding independence, and communicate to them all relationships and other matters that could reasonably be considered to affect my independence, as well as any relevant safeguards where applicable.

From discussions with the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, I determine which matters are most important to the audit of the current financial statements and thus constitute key audit matters. I will describe these matters in the auditor’s report, unless legal or regulatory requirements prohibit public disclosure, or in extremely rare circumstances, where the negative consequences of communicating a matter in my report are reasonably expected to outweigh the public benefit, and I decide not to communicate that matter in the report.

# Exchange Fund: Notes to the Financial Statements

Unless otherwise specified, all amounts are listed in millions of Hong Kong dollars.

# 1 Main Business

The Exchange Fund Manager, acting under the authority delegated by the Financial Secretary in accordance with the Exchange Fund Ordinance (Cap. 66), oversees the management of the Fund. The Fund's primary mandate is to safeguard the Hong Kong dollar's exchange rate and ensure the stability and soundness of Hong Kong's monetary and financial systems.

The fund's assets are allocated to four different portfolios for management: Backing Portfolio, Investment Portfolio, Long-Term Growth Portfolio, and Strategic Asset Portfolio. According to Hong Kong’s monetary issue system, the assets of the Backing Portfolio are fully matched with the monetary base. The Investment Portfolio primarily invests in bond and equity markets of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development member countries. The Long-Term Growth Portfolio holds private equity and real estate investments. The Strategic Asset Portfolio holds shares of Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited, purchased by the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) for strategic purposes and included in the fund’s accounts. Operating segment details are disclosed in Note 31.
